Played 1 time. I don't know how else to say it. This game stinks. It is an older Knizia numbers game in the worst possible way I can use that term. I don't throw '3's around lightly, but this earned it. Far too straightforward and dull, and far too much like Kingdoms, which Knizia also designed. Kingdoms is a VERY similar game (same board, similar pieces) but is a far better game and scales from 2-4 players, where Atlanteon is dull game for 2 players. How this thing rates an average of 6 is beyond me. The other player I played with, who is much more forgiving of numbers games than myself, felt the same way about the game.

Atlanteon feels like a 2P Weiner Walzer without the set-collection. (Yes, I know Atlanteon proceeded WW by 24 years but I played WW first…) On the face of it, that sounds great! (The importance of the set-collection in WW really grates because it is so damned important to your final score.) And, even better in Atlanteon, you have three end-game victory conditions: 1) capture your opponent’s king; 2) capture all three towers; or 3) place your king and all 11 control markers before your opponent.

And, yet, Atlanteon just doesn’t come together in a satisfying way. Placing control markers feels more tit-for-tat than clever. If that’s the case, you can already see that capturing your opponent’s king would likely mean exceptionally poor play. Capturing all three towers similarly seems highly unlikely unless, again, your opponent is playing poorly or not paying attention. (In the latter case, I find *gotcha* wins really unsatisfying.) So, that means most games are going to play out with the king + 11 control maker victory and the whole thing is more ineluctable than electrifying.

I’ll hang on to my weiner (walzer), thank you very much!

This is a very simplistic "area control" game. Essentially it's a similar flavor to a solitaire game in that you can know all the values just not the order you will receive them and the added complication that you have an opponent that is changing the value of your plays.

On the surface this is a very simple game. When I think I do no need it I take it out play it and realize that its simplicity solidifies the raw power and value of this rough gem.

I played this three times. I didn't love it, but I have thought about it a fair amount in the intervening weeks, which is a sign of interesting game design.

Things I liked:
-I always appreciate games designed for two players
-Fast to set up, and fast to play
-Interesting decision points
-Small physical footprint
-Even after three games, I didn't feel that I had much of an understanding of what optimal play looks like. Moves that seemed obviously correct ended up not leading to good outcomes. In other words, the gameplay was deeper than it seemed at first glance.

Things I disliked:
-Extremely dry. The theme is almost nonexistent, and it can be hard to even tell the game pieces of the two sides apart (as they are both shades of blue)
-The rules are relatively simple, but there are some fiddly/inelegant complexities to them. In particular, each player places certain tower pieces at the beginning of the game, but each player places a different number of towers and the towers do different things.

Some of the low scores here are shocking. I played this 3 times back to back and enjoyed each play more than the last. There is MUCH more than meets the eye here. Opportunities for creative play, trap setting, and tough "hand" management considerations that echo the fixed bid pieces in Metropolys' (ie. you might regret using your "hammer" too early, but you may also regret not using it earlier!) Don't listen to the 1's and 2's given by people who have Terraforming Mars and A Feast for Odin in their top 10s. Atlanteon is for serious gamers
